content: The Act is titled the "Taxpayer Responsibility, Accountability, and Consistency Act of 2008". It includes information reporting requirements for payments made to corporations. The "Taxpayer Responsibility, Accountability, and Consistency Act of 2008" amends Section 6041 of the Internal Revenue Code to include information reporting requirements for payments made to corporations, with exceptions for certain hospitals and extended care facilities. The amendment made by the "Taxpayer Responsibility, Accountability, and Consistency Act of 2008" applies to payments made more than 1 year after the enactment date of the Act. SEC. 3. DETERMINATION OF ELIGIBILITY FOR SAFE HARBOR TREATMENT OF INDIVIDUALS AS NON-EMPLOYEES FOR EMPLOYMENT TAXES. New section added to Chapter 25 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, titled "SEC. 3511. SAFE HARBOR." The Safe Harbor provision in the Internal Revenue Code allows taxpayers to treat certain individuals as non-employees for employment taxes if specific conditions are met, including consistent tax filings and a reasonable basis for not treating the individual as an employee. The Safe Harbor provision in the Internal Revenue Code allows taxpayers to treat individuals as non-employees for employment taxes if specific conditions are met, including a reasonable basis for not treating the individual as an employee, which is determined by statutory standards. The Safe Harbor provision in the Internal Revenue Code allows taxpayers to treat individuals as non-employees for employment taxes if specific conditions are met, including a concluded examination of whether the individual should be treated as an employee, with no determination made that they should be treated as an employee. The Safe Harbor provision in the Internal Revenue Code allows individuals to be treated as non-employees for employment taxes if certain conditions are met. The term "employment tax" refers to any tax imposed by this subtitle, and "employment status" is defined as the status of an individual as an employee or independent contractor. Special rules apply for the application of this section, with the IRS required to provide notice before or at the start of any examination related to employment status. The IRS provides written notice to taxpayers regarding the provisions of the Safe Harbor provision in the Internal Revenue Code. Taxpayers cannot rely on examinations or determinations more than 7 years old. The determination of a substantially similar position is made by the Secretary in line with the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. Taxpayers bear the burden of proof to establish entitlement. The taxpayer must prove eligibility for relief under this section with a preponderance of evidence. Individuals can petition for a determination of their employment tax status within 90 days under procedures established by the Secretary. The taxpayer must prove eligibility for relief with evidence. Individuals can petition for a determination of their employment tax status within 90 days. No taxpayer may retaliate against an individual for filing a petition. The paragraph does not diminish individual rights under Federal or State law or collective bargaining agreements. The Secretary must notify the Secretary of Labor and the individual if misclassification is found. Regulations must be prescribed within a year. Conforming amendments are also made. Conforming amendments are made to section 7436(a) of the Revenue Code, replacing "section 530 of the Revenue Act of 1978" with "section 3511". Additionally, a new item is added to the table of sections for chapter 25 of the Code. Section 3511 provides a safe harbor, with the termination of Section 530 of the Revenue Act of 1978 for services rendered more than 1 year after the enactment of this Act. The amendments made by this section apply to services rendered more than 1 year after the enactment of this Act. Additionally, there will be annual reports on worker misclassification. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue an annual report on worker misclassification, including enforcement actions, relief obtained, estimates of misclassified employers and affected workers, impact on the tax system, and outcomes of petitions filed under section 3511(e) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Additionally, there will be an increase in information return penalties. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase penalties for failure to file correct information returns. The penalties are raised from $50 to $250, and from $250,000 to $3,000,000. Corrections made within specified periods will result in reduced penalties, with adjustments made for different timeframes. Section 6721(b)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to increase penalties for failure to file correct information returns. The penalties are raised to $100, $250, and $1,500,000 respectively. Additionally, for persons with gross receipts of not more than $5,000,000, the lower limitation is amended to $1,000,000, $3,000,000, and $175,000. Penalties for failure to file correct information returns under the Internal Revenue Code are increased to $500, $3,000,000, and $1,500,000 respectively. Additionally, penalties for failure to furnish correct payee statements are raised to $250. Penalties for failure to comply with information reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code are increased to $250 and $1,000,000 respectively. Effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2008.
